commit_message:
Refactor the DB implementation of Capabilities API

Replace the update of DEFAULT_CAPABILITIES into the __init__ function in
the Connection class of base.py instead of the Connection class of each
DB driver.

The AVAILABLE_CAPABILITIES dict was divided into two case of MongoDB
and DB2 drivers, the common capabilities are listed in pymongo_base.py
in COMMON_AVAILABLE_CAPABILTIES, which is updated with the capabilities
dict of the two affected DB drivers using pymongo.

Change-Id: I244eabc64f985d5a7ab5e166c72bcdb88b7e3372
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/02/84002/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from ceilometer import utilsCOMMON_AVAILABLE_CAPABILITIES = { 'meters': {'query': {'simple': True, 'metadata': True}}, 'samples': {'query': {'simple': True, 'metadata': True, 'complex': True}}, 'alarms': {'query': {'simple': True, 'complex': True}, 'history': {'query': {'simple': True, 'complex': True}}}, } def __init__(self, conf, AVAILABLE_CAPABILITIES): super(Connection, self).__init__( conf, utils.update_nested(COMMON_AVAILABLE_CAPABILITIES, AVAILABLE_CAPABILITIES))

commit_message:
add exit trap to determine what's failing

grenade does a lot with starting and stopping processes, so if
we get a hard to diagnose fail dump the process list and disk
status.

Change-Id: Ia7377608cdc51067bc418569012df9a81d48e060
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/grenade refs/changes/19/85719/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Setup Exit Traps for debug purposes trap exit_trap EXIT function exit_trap { local r=$? # print out all the processes running echo "Running Processes:" ps auxw echo "Disk Status:" df -h # and just let everything flush sleep 1 exit $r }

commit_message:
Add main developer page

This adds the main ('index') page for developers (to be available
at http://docs.openstack.org/developer/python-ironicclient/).
It has minimal information, and is a place holder so that we can
start adding documentation.

This also fixes issues with 'python setup.py build_sphinx':
- was getting "error: 'source_dir' must be a directory name"
  because sphinx 1.2b3 was being installed instead of 1.1.2
  (see https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-ci/+bug/1259511)
- was getting "sphinx.errors.ExtensionError: Could not import
  extension oslo.sphinx (exception: No module named sphinx)"
- was complaining about missing '_theme' (oslosphinx has the theme)

Change-Id: I47ad7e10c20b80a99ae36755b2f7f67c080676fd
Partial-Bug: #1300990

commit_message:
mark vif_driver as deprecated and log warning

Several classes were dropped from nova.virt.libvirt.vif from havana ->
icehouse, leading to invalid configurations if one of these classes was
used in the libvirt_vif_driver setting in nova.conf.  The error message
produced by nova-compute in this situation is misleading.

This patch introduces stubs for all of the classes that were removed.
These stubs inherit from LibvirtGenericVIFDriver and log a deprecation
warning in __init__.

This patch also marks the vif_driver option as deprecated.

Change-Id: I6d6cb9315ce6f3b33d17756bcdc77dccda26fefe
Closed-bug: 1302796
(cherry picked from commit 9f6070e194504cc2ca2b7f2a2aabbf91c6b81897)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/07/85707/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # The following classes were removed in the transition from Havana to # Icehouse, but may still be referenced in configuration files. The # following stubs allow those configurations to work while logging a # deprecation warning. class _LibvirtDeprecatedDriver(LibvirtGenericVIFDriver): def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): LOG.warn('VIF driver \"%s\" is marked as deprecated and will be ' 'removed in the Juno release.', self.__class__.__name__) super(_LibvirtDeprecatedDriver, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs) class LibvirtBridgeDriver(_LibvirtDeprecatedDriver): pass class LibvirtOpenVswitchDriver(_LibvirtDeprecatedDriver): pass class LibvirtHybridOVSBridgeDriver(_LibvirtDeprecatedDriver): pass class LibvirtOpenVswitchVirtualPortDriver(_LibvirtDeprecatedDriver): pass class NeutronLinuxBridgeVIFDriver(_LibvirtDeprecatedDriver): pass

commit_message:
Use built-in print() instead of print statement

In python 3 print statement is not supported, so we should use
only print() functions.

Fixes bug 1226943

Change-Id: I721e67c917ba7018401ad40ef30081883dcec420

Fix wrong section name "security_group" in sample config files

The section name [security_group] in Sample config files of
ML2 and Big Switch plugins was wrong and it should be
[securitygroup].

commit_message:
Port to Pecan/WSME for API v2

Routing either V1 or V2 using a Facade. By default, V1 is enabled
but can be deactivated by a confflag.

Pecan controller for Lease created using WSME i/o validation

Implements blueprint: pecan-wsme

Change-Id: I9047abece78632daa13fdebfea9fb8aaa3c60981

commit_message:
ceph backup driver: improve log messages

Added additional information to log messages where helpful and tidied
code.

Change-Id: Ie7c54ab970223c6993254069d5d419e1ee90bedb
Closes-Bug: #1279703

commit_message:
Doc's update for integration tests

* Description of tests was changed and complemented;
* List of tests to each plugin and its version was added.

Change-Id: I8de087d745cb83dfc6da67d1bc5036cacd1b6b80
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/71/85071/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: You can take a look at sample config file `/sahara/tests/integration/configs/itest.conf.sample` or `/sahara/tests/integration/configs/itest.conf.sample-full`.Tests can be disabled in the `/sahara/tests/integration/configs/config.py` file**NOTE**: Both `OS_TENANT_ID` and `OS_TENANT_NAME` must be specified in the config file. If you want to run integration tests for one plugin, you should use the corresponding tox env: `tox -e integration -- <tag>`. <tag> may have the following values: transient, vanilla1, vanilla2, hdp, idh2 and idh3. For example, you want to run tests for the Vanilla plugin with the Hadoop version 1.2.1. In this case you should use the following tox env: `tox -e integration -- vanilla1`. If you want to run integration tests for a few plugins or their versions, you should use the corresponding tox env: `tox -e integration -- <tag1>,<tag2>, ...`. For example, you want to run tests for the Vanilla plugin with the Hadoop version 2.3.0 and for the IDH plugin with the Hadoop version 3.0.2. In this case you should use the following tox env: `tox -e integration -- vanilla2,idh3`. Here are a few more examples: `tox -e integration -- transient` will run test for transient cluster; `tox -e integration -- hdp` will run tests for the HDP plugin; `tox -e integration -- transient,vanilla1,idh2` will run test for transient cluster, tests for the Vanilla plugin with the Hadoop version 1.2.1 and tests for the IDH plugin with the Hadoop version 2.5.1.Here are the following checks for the Sahara plugins that tests have: 1. Proper cluster creation. This test creates node group templates, a cluster template and a cluster. All other test checks are executed on the created cluster. 2. Cinder support. When the cluster is built, Cinder volumes are attached to some cluster nodes (two 2 GB volumes per node). When cluster state is "Active", SSH connection is established to nodes which have volumes. On each node the bash command "mount | grep <volume_mount_prefix> | wc -l" is executed and actual result is compared to the expected result. 3. Cluster configs. When the cluster is created, the bash script "sahara/tests/integration/tests/resources/cluster_config_test_script.sh" is copied to all cluster nodes. On all nodes script checks that cluster configs was properly applied. 4. Map Reduce. When the cluster is created, the bash script "sahara/tests/integration/tests/resources/map_reduce_test_script.sh" is copied to all cluster nodes. On the master node this script runs Map Reduce jobs "PI estimator" and "Word count". The input file for the job "Word count" is generated with the bash command "dmesg". On other nodes this script searches the Hadoop logs of completed jobs. 5. Swift availability. When the cluster is created, the bash script "sahara/tests/integration/tests/resources/map_reduce_test_script.sh" is copied to the master node. The script generates a 1 mb file (we'll call it "file1") with bash command "dd if=/dev/urandom of=/tmp/test-file bs=1048576 count=1". The file is copied from local storage to HDFS storage, then it is uploaded from HDFS storage to Swift (the bash command "distcp"). Then the file is downloaded back to HDFS storage from Swift. The file is copied from HDFS storage to local storage (we'll call it "file2"). The script checks that md5 sums of file1 and file2 are equal. 6. Elastic Data Processing (EDP). This test launches 4 types of EDP jobs on the cluster. There are 4 types of EDP jobs: "Pig", "MapReduce", "MapReduce.Streaming" and "Java". 7. Cluster scaling. This test adds 2 new node groups to the cluster (each node group has 1 node), reduces count of nodes in 2 node groups from 1 node to 0 nodes (deletes 2 node groups) and increases count of nodes in 1 node group from 3 nodes to 4 nodes. All steps are executed in the same API request. 8. Transient cluster. In this test the cluster is created as a transient cluster. No jobs are launched on the cluster. So the test checks that cluster will be automatically deleted by Sahara after a while. Vanilla plugin with the Hadoop version 1.2.1 has the following checks: ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ 1. Proper cluster creation. 2. Cinder support. 3. Cluster configs. 4. Map Reduce. 5. Elastic Data Processing (EDP). 6. Swift availability. 7. Cluster scaling. 8. Transient cluster. Vanilla plugin with the Hadoop version 2.3.0 has the following checks: ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ 1. Proper cluster creation. 2. Cinder support. 3. Map Reduce. 4. Elastic Data Processing (EDP). 5. Swift availability. 6. Cluster scaling.1. Proper cluster creation. 2. Cinder support. 3. Map Reduce. 4. Elastic Data Processing (EDP). 5. Swift availability. 6. Cluster scaling. IDH plugin with the Hadoop version 2.5.1 has the following checks: ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ 1. Proper cluster creation. 2. Map Reduce. 3. Swift availability. 4. Cluster scaling. IDH plugin with the Hadoop version 3.0.2 has the following checks: ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ 1. Proper cluster creation. 2. Swift availability. 3. Cluster scaling.
deleted_lines: You can take a look at sample config files - `/sahara/tests/integration/configs/itest.conf.sample`, `/sahara/tests/integration/configs/itest.conf.sample-full`.Tests may be disabled in the `/sahara/tests/integration/configs/config.py` fileIf you want to run integration tests for one plugin or a few plugins you should use the corresponding tox env: `tox -e integration -- <plugin_name>` or `tox -e integration -- <plugin_name_1> <plugin_name_2>`. For example: `tox -e integration -- vanilla` or `tox -e integration vanilla hdp` **NOTE**: Both `OS_TENANT_ID` and `OS_TENANT_NAME` must be specified in config file.These integration tests check capacity for work of two plugins for Sahara: Vanilla and HDP. Vanilla plugin has the following checks: ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ 1. A cluster creation. This test create node group templates, a cluster template and a cluster. All other test checks are performed on created cluster. 2. Test for a check of cluster configs. This test checks presence of desired parameters in cluster configuration files which were specified during the cluster creation. Desired configuration values are checked with GET-request as well as directly in configuration files on the cluster. 3. Test for a check of Elastic Data Processing (EDP). This test launches pig-job with jar-library and jar-job. 4. Test for a check of Hadoop (Map Reduce and HDFS). This test launches Map Reduce jobs "PI estimator" and "Word count". Input file for job "Word count" is generated with the bash command "dmesg". 5. Test for check of Swift availability. This test generates a 1 mb file. The file is uploaded to HDFS storage, then to Swift storage with the command "distcp". Further with the same command "distcp" the 1 mb file is downloaded to HDFS storage from Swift. The 1 mb file is copied from HDFS to local storage and md5 sums of both files is compared (the very first 1 mb file and the latest file downloaded to local storage). 6. Test for a check of cluster scaling. This test add 2 new node groups, resize 2 node groups to 0 nodes and resize 1 node group to 4 nodes. All steps are performed in the same scaling request.1. A cluster creation. This test create node group templates, a cluster template and a cluster. All other test checks are performed on created cluster. 2. Test for a check of Hadoop (Map Reduce and HDFS). This test launches Map Reduce jobs "PI estimator" and "Word count". Input file for job "Word count" is generated with the bash command "dmesg". 3. Test for check of Swift availability. This test generates a 1 mb file. The file is uploaded to HDFS storage, then to Swift storage with the command "distcp". Further with the same command "distcp" the 1 mb file is downloaded to HDFS storage from Swift. The 1 mb file is copied from HDFS to local storage and md5 sums of both files is compared (the very first 1 mb file and the latest file downloaded to local storage). 4. Test for a check of cluster scaling. This test add a 1 new node group and resize 1 node group to 4 nodes. All steps are performed in the same scaling request.

commit_message:
Minor fixes to Sahara UI Installation Guide

 * removed item #7 - it is not needed and is misleading
 * rephrased clarification for AUTO_ASSIGNMENT_ENABLED
 * renamed 'Nova Network' to 'Nova-Network' - seems like the later is
   the only name which is used

Partial-Implements: blueprint update-docs-icehouse
Change-Id: Ibb177820da8d44e1f70a8fd7273dadd57e81ad1e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/10/85710/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: If you are using Neutron instead of Nova-Network: If you are using Nova-Network with ``auto_assign_floating_ip=False`` add the following parameter:7. Create a symlink to sahara-dashboard source8. Modify ``openstack_dashboard/settings.py``9. Start Horizon10. Applying changes
deleted_lines: If you are using Neutron instead of Nova Network: If you are not using nova-network with auto_assign_floating_ip=True, also set:7. Install sahara-dashboard module to Horizon's venv Go to the horizon folder from step 2 and execute .. sourcecode:: console $ .venv/bin/pip install $SAHARA_DASHBOARD_HOME .. 8. Create a symlink to sahara-dashboard source9. Modify ``openstack_dashboard/settings.py``10. Start Horizon11. Applying changes

commit_message:
Added CLI command to import packages

Added CLI command to import Murano packages. Example
murano-manage import-package murano-api/meta/packages/core

Also updated base packages structure.

Change-Id: I82c26ee6d8c675563174cefaa84b44ebdf1b14c4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano refs/changes/24/85624/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Catch exception during resolving outputs

Previously we got error when try to show incorrect outputs.
Now we catch all exceptions and return None value in this case.

Change-Id: I7a7c53c1ad8f42082c89c92cbcb52599a6c7f1f8
Closes-Bug: #1273490
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/86/85686/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_correct_outputs(self): tmpl = {'HeatTemplateFormatVersion': '2012-12-12', 'Resources': { 'AResource': {'Type': 'ResourceWithPropsType', 'Properties': {'Foo': 'abc'}}, 'BResource': {'Type': 'ResourceWithPropsType', 'Properties': {'Foo': 'def'}}}, 'Outputs': { 'Resource_attr': { 'Value': { 'Fn::GetAtt': ['AResource', 'Foo']}}}} self.stack = parser.Stack(self.ctx, 'stack_with_correct_outputs', template.Template(tmpl)) self.stack.store() self.stack.create() self.assertEqual((parser.Stack.CREATE, parser.Stack.COMPLETE), self.stack.state) self.assertEqual('abc', self.stack['AResource'].properties['Foo']) # According _resolve_attribute method in GenericResource output # value will be equal with name AResource. self.assertEqual('AResource', self.stack.output('Resource_attr')) self.stack.delete() self.assertEqual((self.stack.DELETE, self.stack.COMPLETE), self.stack.state) def test_incorrect_outputs(self): tmpl = {'HeatTemplateFormatVersion': '2012-12-12', 'Resources': { 'AResource': {'Type': 'ResourceWithPropsType', 'Properties': {'Foo': 'abc'}}}, 'Outputs': { 'Resource_attr': { 'Value': { 'Fn::GetAtt': ['AResource', 'Bar']}}}} self.stack = parser.Stack(self.ctx, 'stack_with_incorrect_outputs', template.Template(tmpl)) self.stack.store() self.stack.create() self.assertEqual((parser.Stack.CREATE, parser.Stack.COMPLETE), self.stack.state) self.assertIsNone(self.stack.output('Resource_attr')) self.stack.delete() self.assertEqual((self.stack.DELETE, self.stack.COMPLETE), self.stack.state)

commit_message:
fix grub2 installation on Debian Wheezy

--target has been introduced in grub2. This patch ensure we use
the minimal version before adding the --target XXX flag.

Debian Wheezy and Precise share the same limitation regarding the
root device.

Change-Id: I5b3ad42b9fb536d13fb65d84339bc15bc23d99a3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/06/83506/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix deprecation warning in test_multiprocessing

tests/functional/v1/test_multiprocessing uses psutil to get a list of
processes. The Processor class now uses children() instead of
get_children(); update the test with the current call to eliminate
the deprecation warning.

Change-Id: I83a6bb72b5282d3ab2a3b8e338ee3dc8668d2d53
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/57/84257/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add L2 Agent side handling for non consistent security_group settings

Add setting of the firewall_driver to NoopDriver when firewall_driver is None and
add warning if driver combination is not valid.
Modify is_valid_driver_combination to verify default settings: enable_security_group (True) and firewall_driver (None).

Change-Id: I841f9cf96ac6ee2ad17a4e8908d6c8a96f368cca
Closes-Bug: #1296957

commit_message:
Merged in murano-common

In attempt to reduce number of Murano repositories to a sane minumum Murano
community decided to merge in murano-common repo to projects dependent on it:
* murano-api
* murano-agent

We hope that we will completely get rid of this code in Juno.

Change-Id: Id203e62b040ddc2fe67399b2b487eaddca5f564f
Partially-Implements: blueprint repository-reorganization

commit_message:
Grunt task to remove unnecessary static files after compression

As we removed deletion of unnecessary files from iso build script
due to errors, many users were confused as they were trying to
change static files on a master node and there was no effect as
require.js compiles concatenates all the files into main.js. So we
decided to revive this functionality as a part of 'grunt build'

Change-Id: I227616153effcd7ded0ad6617773f46359443b4e

commit_message:
Cardinal interpolation error

-Seems like for the big numbers, d3 is interpolating
 data badly and it is creating loops in the chart.
 So quick fix is to switch to linear interpolation
 as default.
-Other interpolation can be set with settings.

Change-Id: I82c1514dce6034b3cbc7f95682356a08301482b7
Fixes-bug: #1295537
(cherry picked from commit 8bcc5e9703fa4db5e702685a584d2e91fbea7b4a)

commit_message:
Fix alarm metadata in new autoscaling template

The new autoscaling template used old implicit metadata for creating
alarm: the patch fixes that by properly passing a new value to both the
alarms and the servers.

Change-Id: Ia5d99dd08cf02954ce78ef661fbe9f627948f9db

commit_message:
Ensure network interfaces are in requested order

_build_network_info_model was iterating current_neutron_ports
instead of port_ids which contains ports in their correctly requested
order. Because of this the requested nic order was no longer being
perserved. This patch fixes this and also changes the order of ports
in test_build_network_info_model() so this case is tested.

Change-Id: Ia9e71364bca6cbc24ebc1c234e6a5af14f51cd62
Closes-bug: #1300325
(cherry picked from commit 721e7f939859fbfe6b0c79ef3a6d5e43c916da65)

commit_message:
Add a custom filter method to scan wrapped dict results

Basic filtering is available via Resource._filter_fields and
Resource._children but partial filtering of fields is not supported.

This change allows a Resource to define custom sanitization methods
for individual fields. The specified method is applied after the
field has been generated.

For nested structures, particularly when elements are not Resource
types, it is easier to scan the field after generation and remove
specific elements than it is to modify the recursive descent already
implemented in to_wrapped_dict().

JobExecutions are filtered with this mechanism to set swift credential
values to empty strings and to remove the 'conf' section reported
for running Oozie actions.

Closes-Bug: #1300291
Change-Id: Ifb0b99a3e13d40306139b0d0021aead69e870205

commit_message:
Add required_parameters validator

With this validator we can validate required parameters for a given
benchmark by putting decorator like following:-
@valid.add_validator(valid.required_parameters([list of parameters])

Change-Id: I87a848d06f631da021a74b7ab3d970c3fe892115
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/61/84961/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def required_parameters(params): def required_parameters_validator(**kwargs): for param in params: if param not in kwargs: message = _(" '%s parameter not defined in " "the benchmark config file") % param return ValidationResult(False, message) return ValidationResult() return required_parameters_validator

commit_message:
Note that XML support *may* be removed.

To be more accurate, note that XML support *may* be removed as early
as the Juno release.  I think there is still more discussion needed
around concrete usage data before the removal date is finalized.

Related thread:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-April/031608.html

Closes-bug: #1301384
Change-Id: I0415b50ec0b81bb56f5c0fa13bc6d01f8bec7865
(cherry picked from commit 5d39189df6ecb559c3f8b7e2fa3beff25da9f452)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/09/85709/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: LOG.warning(_('XML support has been deprecated and may be removed ' 'as early as the Juno release.'))
deleted_lines: LOG.warning(_('XML support has been deprecated and will be removed ' 'in the Juno release.'))

commit_message:
Disable check_uptodate.sh check in pep8

Running generate_sample.sh currently produces an invalid heat.conf.sample
due to bug #1288586.

This change disables the check_uptodate.sh in the tox pep8 so that the
gate-heat-pep8 job passes while we find a more appropriate solution.

Change-Id: Ib20c4f892df68f7112d969d801a18a1a5bfbd474
Related-Bug: #1288586
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/15/85915/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # disable check_uptodate until a resolution is found to bug #1288586 #{toxinidir}/tools/config/check_uptodate.sh

commit_message:
Correct update to zero numbers of health monitors

If property 'monitors' is in prop_diff and equals to None ot [],
we should not skip dissociating step for monitors.

Change-Id: I313a8e09dbeeab78126ff889316f0ecb1a9a8c84
Closes-Bug: #1301406

commit_message:
Remove __del__ usage in oslo.vmware driver

The driver uses __del__ in which may cause spurious errors.
python docs detail the caveats of using __del__.

In order to enable the calling application to be able to close
existing sessions, a new method has been added: logout.
This will be used to terminate and logout of the existing session.

Change-Id: I94482b79cc451d027cb853a6d0775e4da189cb7e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.vmware refs/changes/81/82781/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: def __del__(self): """Log out and terminate the current session.""" if self._session_id: LOG.info(_("Logging out and terminating the current session with " "ID = %s."), self._session_id) try: self.vim.Logout(self.vim.service_content.sessionManager) except Exception: LOG.exception(_("Error occurred while logging out and " "terminating the current session with " "ID = %s."), self._session_id) else: LOG.debug(_("No session exists to log out."))

commit_message:
libvirt: pause mode is not supported by all drivers

Only KVM/Qemu drivers support the VIR_DOMAIN_START_PAUSED flag
Booting guests on other drivers with the above flag will make it fail.

Closes-Bug: 1301453
Change-Id: Ia98e018b686c4ec3c15fd1f6bcc78188f330fcef
(cherry picked from commit bfb28fcf9031af4c695177663702ce05edbbfa4d)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/08/85708/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Removes default usage of root-passwd element from HDP image generation

This patch removes the root-passwd element from the list of elements
  in the HDP image generation process.
It was determined that having root-passwd included causes some problems on
  RHEL, and is also a potential security issue.
This patch modifies the default cause, such that root-passwd is not
  included in HDP images.  In order to support local debugging of
  generated images, this patch adds a "-d" (debug) flag that can be
  enabled in order to add root-passwd to the HDP images. If not
  specified, the debugging flag defaults to false (not
  including root-passwd).
This patch updates the usage log to explain the usage of the
  -d parameter.

Change-Id: I1692916a3d7c08b8a3b180913e6fca3547a2e2bc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara-image-elements refs/changes/43/85143/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # default debug setting should be false IMAGE_GENERATION_DEBUG_MODE="false" while getopts "p:i:v:d:" opt; do d) IMAGE_GENERATION_DEBUG_MODE=$OPTARG ;; echo "Usage: $(basename $0) [-p vanilla|spark|hdp|idh] [-i ubuntu|fedora|centos] [-v 1|2|plain] [-d true|false]" echo "'-p' is plugin version, '-i' is image type, '-v' is hadoop version, '-d controls the debug mode for image generation (false by default)" echo "Debug mode should only be enabled for local debugging purposes, not for production systems"if [ -n "$IMAGE_GENERATION_DEBUG_MODE" -a "$IMAGE_GENERATION_DEBUG_MODE" != "true" -a "$IMAGE_GENERATION_DEBUG_MODE" != "false" ]; then echo -e "Unknown debug mode.\nAborting" exit 1 fi if [ -z "$IMAGE_GENERATION_DEBUG_MODE" -o "$IMAGE_GENERATION_DEBUG_MODE" = "true" ]; then echo "Using HDP Image Debug Mode, using root-pwd in images, NOT FOR PRODUCTION USAGE." # Each image has a root login, password is "hadoop" export DIB_PASSWORD="hadoop" fi centos_elements_sequence="vm rhel hadoop-hdp disable-firewall redhat-lsb sahara-version source-repositories yum" if [ -z "$IMAGE_GENERATION_DEBUG_MODE" -o "$IMAGE_GENERATION_DEBUG_MODE" = "true" ]; then # enable the root-pwd element, for simpler local debugging of images centos_elements_sequence=$centos_elements_sequence" root-passwd" fi centos_elements_sequence="vm rhel hadoop-hdp disable-firewall redhat-lsb sahara-version source-repositories yum" if [ -z "$IMAGE_GENERATION_DEBUG_MODE" -o "$IMAGE_GENERATION_DEBUG_MODE" = "true" ]; then # enable the root-pwd element, for simpler local debugging of images centos_elements_sequence=$centos_elements_sequence" root-passwd" fi centos_plain_elements_sequence="vm rhel redhat-lsb sahara-version yum" if [ -z "$IMAGE_GENERATION_DEBUG_MODE" -o "$IMAGE_GENERATION_DEBUG_MODE" = "true" ]; then # enable the root-pwd element, for simpler local debugging of images centos_elements_sequence=$centos_elements_sequence" root-passwd" fi
deleted_lines: while getopts "p:i:v:" opt; do echo "Usage: $(basename $0) [-p vanilla|spark|hdp|idh] [-i ubuntu|fedora|centos] [-v 1|2|plain]" echo "'-p' is plugin version, '-i' is image type, '-v' is hadoop version" # Each image has a root login, password is "hadoop" export DIB_PASSWORD="hadoop" centos_elements_sequence="vm rhel hadoop-hdp disable-firewall redhat-lsb root-passwd sahara-version source-repositories yum" centos_elements_sequence="vm rhel hadoop-hdp disable-firewall redhat-lsb root-passwd sahara-version source-repositories yum" centos_plain_elements_sequence="vm rhel redhat-lsb root-passwd sahara-version yum"

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-04 06:25:57.000000000', 'files': ['nova/api/openstack/compute/schemas/v3/floating_ip_dns.py', 'nova/api/openstack/compute/plugins/v3/floating_ip_dns.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/0df3993ca7f3a445d9118dcf3f7a971e6249c68c', 'message': 'Add API schema for v3 floating_ip_dns API

By defining the API schema, it is possible to separate the validation
code from the API method. The API method can be more simple.
In addition, a response of API validation error can be consistent for
the whole Nova API.

Partially implements blueprint nova-api-validation-fw

Change-Id: I6f2d99f4eb26ed578ed2c8fe3724c314002e8a05
'}]
commit_message:
Add API schema for v3 floating_ip_dns API

By defining the API schema, it is possible to separate the validation
code from the API method. The API method can be more simple.
In addition, a response of API validation error can be consistent for
the whole Nova API.

Partially implements blueprint nova-api-validation-fw

Change-Id: I6f2d99f4eb26ed578ed2c8fe3724c314002e8a05
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/20/70920/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.api.openstack.compute.schemas.v3 import floating_ip_dnsfrom nova.api import validation @validation.schema(floating_ip_dns.domain_update) entry = body['domain_entry'] scope = entry['scope'] if scope == 'private' and project: msg = _("project can't be specified with 'private' scope") raise webob.exc.HTTPBadRequest(explanation=msg) if scope == 'public' and av_zone: msg = _("availability_zone can't be specified with 'public' scope") raise webob.exc.HTTPBadRequest(explanation=msg) @validation.schema(floating_ip_dns.entry_update) entry = body['dns_entry'] address = entry['ip'] dns_type = entry['dns_type']
deleted_lines: try: entry = body['domain_entry'] scope = entry['scope'] except (TypeError, KeyError): raise webob.exc.HTTPBadRequest() if (scope not in ('private', 'public') or project and av_zone or scope == 'private' and project or scope == 'public' and av_zone): raise webob.exc.HTTPBadRequest() try: entry = body['dns_entry'] address = entry['ip'] dns_type = entry['dns_type'] except (TypeError, KeyError): raise webob.exc.HTTPBadRequest()

'}, {'number': 8, 'created': '2014-02-19 14:53:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/f6f1f4afc2f8f4594b218f92118b79539ca6609f', 'message': 'Tune mysql, galera, sqlalchemy backend settings

- Tune MySQL config settings to be more clouds-specific (reads much
  more common, reads:writes rate is 10(100):1)
  * Limit innodb_buffer_pool_size to 10G
  * Reduce innodb_write_io_threads
  * Use sql_low_priority_updates
  * Raise FD imits to 102400, max connections, open tables limits etc.
- Tune SQLAlchemy backend settings for Openstack (QueuePool related)
- Sync some MySQL+galera class params for MySQL class as well

Closes-bug: #1274784
Implements blueprint: optimize-db-performance-at-scale

Change-Id: I0e843022f04f53150da52858280034aad6aee987
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>

- Tune MySQL config settings to be more clouds-specific (reads much

  * If there is no mysql/wsrep config exists yet, delete ib_logfile* and
    set innodb_log_file_size as 25% of innodb_buffer_pool_size (max 2G).
    Otherwise, recommend to update it appropriately.
  * Reduce innodb_write_io_threads
  * Use innodb_flush_log_at_trx_commit=2 for HA
  * Raise FD imits to 102400, max connections, open tables limits etc.
- Tune SQLAlchemy backend settings for Openstack (QueuePool related)

'}, {'number': 22, 'created': '2014-02-24 17:53:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/b94fad0594144ec479fa9b2913e389ea41c09870', 'message': 'Tune mysql, galera, sqlalchemy backend settings

- Tune MySQL config settings to be more clouds-specific (reads much
  more common, reads:writes rate is 10(100):1)
  * Limit innodb_buffer_pool_size to 10G
  * If there is no mysql/wsrep config exists yet, delete ib_logfile* and
    set innodb_log_file_size as 25% of innodb_buffer_pool_size (max 2G).
    Otherwise, use existing ib_logfile0 to evaluate its size value.
  * Reduce innodb_write_io_threads
  * Use innodb_flush_log_at_trx_commit=2 for HA
  * Raise FD imits to 102400, max connections, open tables limits etc.
- Tune SQLAlchemy backend settings for Openstack (QueuePool related)
- Sync some MySQL+galera class params for MySQL class as well

Closes-bug: #1274784
Implements blueprint: optimize-db-performance-at-scale

Change-Id: I0e843022f04f53150da52858280034aad6aee987
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>
'}, {'number': 23, 'created': '2014-02-25 13:44:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/14941b0aba6b787f67c0078e948d1b665d2a4084', 'message': 'Tune mysql, galera, sqlalchemy backend settings

- Tune MySQL config settings to be more clouds-specific (reads much
  more common, reads:writes rate is 10(100):1)
  * Limit innodb_buffer_pool_size to 10G
  * Update innodb_log_file_size as:
    * If mysql ib_logfiles do not match 25% of innodb_buffer_pool_size (max 2G),
      delete them and update innodb_log_file_size in the config appropriately;
    * Otherwise, use existing ib_logfile0 size to re-evaluate the
      innodb_buffer_pool_size config value to match its real size.
  * Reduce innodb_write_io_threads
  * Use innodb_flush_log_at_trx_commit=2 for HA
  * Raise FD imits to 102400, max connections, open tables limits etc.
- Tune SQLAlchemy backend settings for Openstack (QueuePool related)
- Sync some MySQL+galera class params for MySQL class as well

Closes-bug: #1274784
Implements blueprint: optimize-db-performance-at-scale

Change-Id: I0e843022f04f53150da52858280034aad6aee987
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>

  * Reduce innodb_write_io_threads
  * Use innodb_flush_log_at_trx_commit=2 for HA
  * Raise FD imits to 102400, max connections, open tables limits etc.
- Tune SQLAlchemy backend settings for Openstack (QueuePool related)
- Sync some MySQL+galera class params for MySQL class as well

Closes-bug: #1274784
Implements blueprint: optimize-db-performance-at-scale

Change-Id: I0e843022f04f53150da52858280034aad6aee987
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>
'}, {'number': 25, 'created': '2014-02-27 09:23:25.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/3496f6f429b8354182767817e4d2b7ba844fc2b0', 'message': 'Tune mysql, galera, sqlalchemy backend settings

- Tune MySQL config settings to be more clouds-specific (reads much
  more common, reads:writes rate is 10(100):1)
  * Limit innodb_buffer_pool_size to 10G
  * Update innodb_log_file_size as:
    * If mysql ib_logfiles do not match 25% of innodb_buffer_pool_size (max 2G),
      delete them and update innodb_log_file_size in the config appropriately;
    * Otherwise, use existing ib_logfile0 size to re-evaluate the
      innodb_buffer_pool_size config value to match its real size.
  * Reduce innodb_write_io_threads
  * Use innodb_flush_log_at_trx_commit=2 for HA
  * Raise FD imits to 102400, max connections, open tables limits etc.
- Tune SQLAlchemy backend settings for Openstack (QueuePool related)
- Sync some MySQL+galera class params for MySQL class as well

Closes-bug: #1274784
Implements blueprint: optimize-db-performance-at-scale

Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>

commit_message:
Tune sqlalchemy backend settings for OS on scale

- Tune SQLAlchemy backend settings for Openstack (QueuePool related)
- Evaluate sqlalchemy backend scaling parameters at osnailyfactor
- Fix deprecated in I [DEFAULT] usage for database config
- For Neutron use neutron_config[:database] as well
    * Ensure max_pool_size in [10, 30] limits (10 is config defaults)
    * Ensure max_overflow in [20, 60] limits (20 is config defaults)

Closes-bug: #1274784
Partial blueprint: optimize-db-performance-at-scale

Change-Id: I0e843022f04f53150da52858280034aad6aee987
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/34/73634/23 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #TODO(bogdando) fix deprecated names in I # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/sql_max_pool_size > [DATABASE]/max_pool_size # Deprecated group/name - [DATABASE]/sql_max_pool_size # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/sql_max_retries > [DATABASE]/max_retries # Deprecated group/name - [DATABASE]/sql_max_retries # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/sql_max_overflow > [DATABASE]/max_overflow # Deprecated group/name - [DATABASE]/sql_max_overflow neutron_config { 'DEFAULT/sql_max_pool_size': value => min($::processorcount * 5, 30); 'DEFAULT/sql_max_retries': value => '-1'; 'DEFAULT/sql_max_overflow': value => min($::processorcount * 10, 60); }

commit_message:
Add API schema for v3 floating_ips API

By defining the API schema, it is possible to separate the validation
code from the API method. The API method can be more simple.
In addition, a response of API validation error can be consistent for
the whole Nova API.

Partially implements blueprint nova-api-validation-fw

Change-Id: I6663f49d06e3b6129656c69d78c9a5dfb47b4932

commit_message:
VMware: Fixes the instance resize problem

The fix includes separating out methods for
associating/disassociating a vsphere vm from the
openstack instance. Modifying the resize workflow
to use the above mentioned methods.

Closes-Bug: #1295381

Change-Id: I92acdd5cd00f739d504738413d3b63a2e17f2866

commit_message:
Add logging handler for openstack_auth in the tests

Without it, log output below ERROR level can also be displayed in the
tests output.

Change-Id: I342b20fc26468a41843496f11db3e0079b50505c
Closes-Bug: #1218462

commit_message:
Removes the service stop call for gmetad

This patch fixes bug 1302130.  The call to "gmetad stop" has been
  removed from the post-install.d/40-turn-off-gmetad script,  since
  this command will run on the host machine, rather than on the
  generated image.  Only the call the chkconfig to keep
  gmetad from starting is required to achieve the desired affect of
  keeping gmetad from starting upon image boot.

Fixes: bug # 1302130

Change-Id: I97a549be89212e19b84030f156ae9b175b113df4

commit_message:
PR plugin uses host name to query Nova inventory

Use host hypervisor_name instead of host id to query the Nova inventory
to avoid not found errors.

Change-Id: I32c3e8e71354f46ac947ecc8ee8b575e29dd23c1
Closes-Bug: #1299341

commit_message:
Provide rootwrap configuration options

Our tools now generate tables for the rootwrap.conf files. Include this
tables in the config-reference guide. The cinder-rootwrap.xml file is
not used ATM, because our cinder documentation doesn't provide a config
overview (see bug #1304172).

Revert some help strings for nova to what they are in icehouse (the
previous run of the tool accidentally picked up the juno options).

Change-Id: Id3a76cc5ae29b7cf45118958520126ec8f75853d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/23/85923/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
Description of configuration options for rootwrap
Configuration option = Default value Description
[DEFAULT]
filters_path = /etc/nova/rootwrap.d,/usr/share/nova/rootwrap List of directories to load filter definitions from (separated by ','). These directories MUST all be only writeable by root !
exec_dirs = /sbin,/usr/sbin,/bin,/usr/bin List of directories to search executables in, in case filters do not explicitely specify a full path (separated by ',') If not specified, defaults to system PATH environment variable. These directories MUST all be only writeable by root !
use_syslog = False Enable logging to syslog Default value is False
syslog_log_facility = syslog Which syslog facility to use. Valid values include auth, authpriv, syslog, user0, user1... Default value is 'syslog'
syslog_log_level = ERROR Which messages to log. INFO means log all usage ERROR means only log unsuccessful attempts

commit_message:
Catching no handled exception on leases deletion

Catching Conflict exception coming from NovaClient when creating
an image is not possible due to invalid vm_state.
Also, adding new test to cover the scenario being fixed.

Closes-Bug: #1299467
Change-Id: I22113ebebed74e72578fbc6baecdd8d0a462bf22

commit_message:
Duplicated lease name should return HTTP 409

Added new manager exception 'LeaseNameAlreadyExists',
wraps db exception ClimateDBDuplicateEntry occures during lease creation
and returns in the API as:
HTTP 409 The lease with name: %(name)s already exists

Current implementation returns HTTP 500 Internal server error,
which is not user friendly.

Change-Id: I3ead720eda9b08980e3ee7c5cf878354b5455877
Closes-Bug: #1302584\
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/blazar refs/changes/78/85678/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: except db_ex.ClimateDBDuplicateEntry: LOG.exception('Cannot create a lease - duplicated lease name') raise exceptions.LeaseNameAlreadyExists(name=lease_values['name'])

commit_message:
Removes volumes redefinition in fake nova_client

Reasons:
- The redefinition of nova_client.volumes was making it,
  nova_client.volumes.volumes, if we needed to call the volume APIs
  from nova_client.
- nova_client.volumes is already defined when defining "class FakeClient".

Changes:
- Removes redefinition of nova_client.volumes.

Change-Id: I5981d461e5a0fd000214c35d5d0be58d86d6d368
Closes-Bug: #1292457

commit_message:
Add save_admin_pass property to CloudServer

This adds a save_admin_pass property to indicate whether or not the
admin_pass should be persisted in heat.  save_admin_pass is False by
default.

Implements: blueprint custom-adminpass (partial)
Change-Id: Iac59056abf2cf709ecb940b84c56d09fa3fbb7d4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/81/79481/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add admin_pass as attribute to CloudServer

This stores the admin password returned by nova() as an encrypted
property on the CloudServer to allow template authors to display them
as outputs of a stack.

Co-Authored-By: Anderson Mesquita <andersonvom@gmail.com>
Implements: blueprint custom-adminpass (partial)

commit_message:
BigSwitch: Stop HTTP patch before overriding

Stops the default HTTPConnection patch used by the
Big Switch tests before patching HTTPConnection with
another substitution. This prevents mock from losing
track of the default patch which was resulting in it
not consistently being stopped by the stopall call in
cleanup.

This also corrects an incorrectly targeted mock for the
HTTP patch in one of the test files.

Closes-Bug: #1303605
Change-Id: Ia5b374c5f8d3a7905d915de4f1f8d4f3a6f0e58d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/17/85917/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: HTTPCON = 'neutron.plugins.bigswitch.servermanager.HTTPConnection' self.httpPatch.stop() self.httpPatch.start()

commit_message:
Indent code so that is readable

It was only pointed out to me that devtest_overcloud.sh performs updates. I
saw the if statement before but never figured that the next bunch of lines
was only run as part of an create.

Change-Id: I86ae2c8ac595d72fa5f9b4f2b98b8afea06000a5

commit_message:
Fix _validate_mac_address method

The method _validate_mac_address previously used: netaddr.EUI(data)
which would convert data passed in to the correct mac_address representation.
For example if data=123 it would return: EUI('00-00-00-00-00-7B'). To fix
this issue I used netaddr.valid_mac() instead which returns a bool if a mac is
valid or not and does not raise. Note this file needs some improvements to
improve how exception handling is done that will come later.

Change-Id: I4fb868e40abbad9e743028cc768f47ca9b3e0e70
Closes-bug: 1291163
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/57/80757/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: valid_mac = False try: valid_mac = netaddr.valid_mac(_validate_no_whitespace(data)) except Exception: pass finally: # TODO(arosen): The code in this file should be refactored # so it catches the correct exceptions. _validate_no_whitespace # raises AttributeError if data is None. if valid_mac is False: msg = _("'%s' is not a valid MAC address") % data LOG.debug(msg) return msg
deleted_lines: try: netaddr.EUI(_validate_no_whitespace(data)) except Exception: msg = _("'%s' is not a valid MAC address") % data LOG.debug(msg) return msg

commit_message:
Fix wrong section name "security_group" in sample config files

The section name [security_group] in Sample config files of
ML2 and Big Switch plugins was wrong and it should be
[securitygroup].

Change-Id: I8204b2f37f96a5e46038e117853ac8637a9705fd
Closes-Bug: #1304105

commit_message:
pci request mark interface

PCI request identify by uuid, request_id will be saved
into the pci device object while allocation. the device
then can be identify by this uuid.

Change-Id: Ic83f2cc080aa044a1e7b828c463c6e8f62483f47
Signed-off-by: Yongli He <yongli.he@intel.com>

commit_message:
Enhance PCI alias to support pci flavor attr

Currently PCI alias can support only vendor_id/product_id as keys,
and we need enhance it to support all potential keys from pci_flavor_attrs.

Change-Id: I8a21cbd5582454cae8525426f268de4482287e0f
Signed-off-by: Yunhong Jiang <yunhong.jiang@intel.com>

commit_message:
PCI: interface for populate metadata and filter

The network parser should convert the pci flavor in the --nic option
to pci request and save them into instance meta data.

The filter scheduler also should populate the request from metadata
for filter.

bp:pci-extra-info
Sined-off-by: Yongli He <yongli.he@intel.com>
Change-Id: I55cd6f411345faace26b6f416b5ba4298986303e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/68/63268/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _populate_pci_filter_properties(self, request_spec): """populate pci requests from alias, pci-flavor, SRIOV...""" pci_requests = pci_request.get_pci_requests_from_alias( request_spec.get('instance_type') or {}) pci_requests += pci_request.get_pci_requests_from_pci_flavor( request_spec.get('instance_type') or {}) return pci_requests pci_requests = self._populate_pci_filter_properties(request_spec)

commit_message:
PCI stats group on demand

Control node has PCI flavors which allow the administrator to package up
PCI devices for users. Flavor has a name, and matching expression that
selects available (offered by white list) devices.

PCI flavor is defined by a set of (k,v), the k is the PCI property. Not
every PCI property is available to PCI flavor, only a specific set of PCI
property can used to define the PCI flavor, it's global to cloud. These
PCI properties are defined via a global configuration :

  pci_flavor_attrs = ["vendor_id", ...]

pci stats also report stats pool base on pci_flavor_attrs's attrs list.

bp:pci-extra-info
Sined-off-by: Yongli He <yongli.he@intel.com>
Change-Id: Iad4430a4f7461c7ac4a9fa5c76057db136831e4f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/67/63267/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import jsonschemafrom nova.objects import pci_devicefrom oslo.config import cfg pci_stats_opts = [ cfg.StrOpt('pci_stats_group_key', default='["product_id","vendor_id","extra_info"]', help='How pci group the device. ' 'This allows users to specify the how the pci stats ' 'grouping the device, For example: ' 'pci_stats_group_key = ' '["product_id", "vendor_id", "extra_info"]' ) ] CONF = cfg.CONF CONF.register_opts(pci_stats_opts) _GROUP_KEY_SCHEMA = { "type": "array", "items": { "type": "string" }, "minItems": 1, "uniqueItems": True } pool_keys = () # spec, extra_spec try: group_keys = jsonutils.loads(CONF.pci_stats_group_key) jsonschema.validate(group_keys, _GROUP_KEY_SCHEMA) except Exception as e: raise exception.PciConfigInvalidGroupKey(reason=str(e)) group_dict = dict(zip(group_keys, range(len(group_keys)))) spec, extra_spec = pci_device.PciDevice.extract_extra(group_dict) self.pool_keys = (spec.keys(), extra_spec.keys()) for prop in self.pool_keys[0]) and \ all(dev.extra_info.get(prop) == entry.get(prop) for prop in self.pool_keys[1]) pool = dict((k, dev.get(k)) for k in self.pool_keys[0]) extra = dict((k, dev.extra_info.get(k)) for k in self.pool_keys[1]) pool.update(extra) # pool's key is flat, no extra info
deleted_lines: from nova.openstack.common import log as logging LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) pool_keys = ['product_id', 'vendor_id', 'extra_info'] for prop in self.pool_keys) pool = dict((k, dev.get(k)) for k in self.pool_keys)

commit_message:
Raise execution failure instead of type error

On a request to schedule a unknown node type
raise a execution failure instead of a type
error to ensure that we throw a common set of
exceptions from the engine execution code. To
retain the cause of the execution failure set
the exception cause as the type error so that
this information is retained.

Breaking change: anyone catching type error will
have to switch to catching the more uniform engine
execution failure instead.

Change-Id: Ief27284512df8df549bfd84147ccc6d08f9ef728
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/86/83986/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from taskflow.utils import reflection cause = TypeError("Unknown node type: %s" % (reflection.get_class_name(node))) raise excp.ExecutionFailure("Unknown how to schedule node: %s" % (node), cause=cause)
deleted_lines: raise TypeError("Unknown how to schedule node %s" % node)

commit_message:
Add jobboard tools

- In order for people to easily try out
  the job and board concept with zookeeper (the
  current default impl) it is useful to have a
  simple example script that can be used to do
  this as part of the taskflow core tree (but not
  under the main code, but as a tool/example).
- Include a simple script to download & run zookeeper
  as well, so this process is not as hard for folks

Change-Id: I9a84c61134d92a5750b672176c61e20c98a53bcd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/93/62093/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env python import contextlib import optparse import os import random import sys import tempfile import time import traceback top_dir = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), os.pardir)) sys.path.insert(0, top_dir) from taskflow import engines from taskflow import exceptions as excp from taskflow.jobs.backends import impl_zookeeper from taskflow.openstack.common import uuidutils from taskflow.patterns import linear_flow from taskflow.persistence.backends import impl_dir from taskflow.persistence import logbook from taskflow import task BOARD_NAME = 'The-One-Board' # How long idling lasts for... IDLE_FREQ = 5.0 * random.random() # 1/3 of the time we will post jobs POST_CHOICES = (True, False, False) # STEP 0: # # Get zookeeper running somewhere (say a VM) # # http://zookeeper.apache.org/doc/r3.3.4/zookeeperStarted.html (standalone) # # Get another VM, then login multiple times (or multiple screen sessions) # # STEP 1: # # Run this program (as a work provider) # $ python work.py -a "$ZK_HOST:2181" -p # # Run this program (as a work consumer) # $ python work.py -a "$ZK_HOST:2181" # # WATCH THE MAGIC!! def print_info(text): print("INFO: %s" % (text)) def print_warning(text): print("WARNING: %s" % (text)) def name(obj): return "%s/%s" % (obj.name, obj.uuid) class Step(task.Task): def __init__(self, step_id): super(Step, self).__init__(name="s-%s" % (step_id)) self._step_id = step_id def execute(self): print(self._step_id) def work_creator(made_for): f = linear_flow.Flow(made_for) for i in range(0, 3): f.add(Step(i)) return f def provider_loop(board, backend, name): # Periodically make work... job_c = 0 while True: post_job = random.choice(POST_CHOICES) if post_job: book = logbook.LogBook("%s/%s" % (name, job_c)) with contextlib.closing(backend.get_connection()) as conn: conn.save_logbook(book) job_c += 1 # This will inject a flow_detail into the book that we just created # allowing some other entity to work on it later. engines.detail_from_factory(work_creator, factory_args=[name], backend=backend, book=book) print_info("Posting job for logbook %s" % (name(book))) try: j = board.post(book.name, book) print_info("Posted job %s" % (name(j))) except excp.ConnectionFailure: print_warning("WARNING: Failed posting '%s'" % (name(j))) traceback.print_exc() else: print_info("Idle loop activating...") time.sleep(IDLE_FREQ) def work_job(board, backend, name, job, listener): print_info("Attempting job '%s' (by worker: %s)" % (name(job), name)) try: # Steps this goes through. # 1) Load what the job actually is from the backend. book = job.book if book is None: raise excp.TaskFlowException("Job %s does not have a valid logbook" ", unknown how to work on a job" " without details on what that job" " is" % (job.name)) # 2) Go through the flow details in that logbook, and attempt to # work on it if that flow details is not finished (which means if # the flow details is partially completed that we will resume it and # attempt to finish it). print(" - Running contents of book '%s'" % (name(book))) for flow_detail in book: # Load an engine that can complete that work. try: engine = engines.load_from_detail(flow_detail, engine_conf={ # Simpler for now... 'engine': 'serial', }, backend=backend) listener.associate(engine) print_info(" - Running contents of flow '%s'" % name(flow_detail)) try: engine.run() finally: listener.disassociate(engine) except (ImportError, ValueError) as e: raise excp.TaskFlowException("Failure at loading engine for" " %s: %s" % (flow_detail.name, e)) try: with contextlib.closing(backend.get_connection()) as conn: conn.destroy_logbook(book.uuid) except excp.TaskFlowException: print_warning("WARNING: Unable to destroy logbook '%s' after" " finishing job '%s'" % (name(book), name(job))) traceback.print_exc() except excp.TaskFlowException: print_warning("WARNING: Didn't finish '%s'" % (name(job))) traceback.print_exc() try: board.abandon(job, name) except excp.InvalidJobOperation: pass else: try: board.consume(job, name) except excp.InvalidJobOperation: pass def worker_loop(board, backend, name): while True: print_info("Scanning for jobs on '%s'" % (board.name)) claimed_jobs = [] # TODO(harlowja): allow for not having to iterate (but instead be # notified of new jobs instead). for job in board.iterjobs(only_unclaimed=True): try: claimed_jobs.append((job, board.claim(job, name))) except (excp.UnclaimableJobException, excp.JobNotFound): pass if not claimed_jobs: print_info("Idle loop activating...") time.sleep(IDLE_FREQ) else: for (job, listener) in claimed_jobs: work_job(board, backend, name, job, listener) def main(): parser = optparse.OptionParser() parser.add_option("-p", "--provider", dest='provider', default=False, action="store_true", help="run as a worker provider " "(default: %default)") parser.add_option("-a", "--address", dest='address', default=impl_zookeeper.DEF_HOSTS, action="store", help="zookeeper address " "(default: %default)") parser.add_option("-d", "--dir", dest='directory', default=os.path.join(tempfile.gettempdir(), "taskflow"), action="store", help="taskflow storage directory" " (default: %default)") (options, args) = parser.parse_args() # Andddd go! storage_conf = { 'path': options.directory, } storage_backend = impl_dir.DirBackend(storage_conf) with contextlib.closing(storage_backend): # Ensure upgraded (if needed). with contextlib.closing(storage_backend.get_connection()) as conn: conn.upgrade() my_id = uuidutils.generate_uuid() board = impl_zookeeper.ZookeeperJobBoard(name=BOARD_NAME, hosts=options.address, loader=storage_backend) board.connect() with contextlib.closing(board): if options.provider: provider_loop(board, storage_backend, "provider-%s" % (my_id)) else: worker_loop(board, storage_backend, "worker-%s" % (my_id)) if __name__ == '__main__': main()

commit_message:
Work around the sqlite3 bug by using tempfiles

Instead of using in-memory backends with threaded
engines, since it appears sqlite does not correctly
handle or recommend multiple threads using the same
:in-memory: backend.

Closes-Bug: #1253673

Change-Id: I7a7ded414d8786f501ec705d132a4aa20e6ef1cb

added_lines: import tempfile@contextlib.contextmanager def make_backend(): def safe_remove(filename): if not filename: return try: os.unlink(filename) except OSError: pass filename = None try: try: backend_uri = sys.argv[1] except Exception: filename = tempfile.mktemp(suffix='.db') backend_uri = 'sqlite:///%s' % (filename) backend = backends.fetch({'connection': backend_uri}) backend.get_connection().upgrade() except Exception: safe_remove(filename) raise try: yield backend finally: safe_remove(filename)with make_backend() as backend: try: book_id, flow_id = sys.argv[2].split("+", 1) except (IndexError, ValueError): book_id = None flow_id = None if not all([book_id, flow_id]): # If no 'tracking id' (think a fedex or ups tracking id) is provided # then we create one by creating a logbook (where flow details are # stored) and creating a flow detail (where flow and task state is # stored). The combination of these 2 objects unique ids (uuids) # allows the users of taskflow to reassociate the workflows that were # potentially running (and which may have partially completed) back # with taskflow so that those workflows can be resumed (or reverted) # after a process/thread/engine has failed in someway. logbook = p_utils.temporary_log_book(backend) flow_detail = p_utils.create_flow_detail(flow, logbook, backend) print("!! Your tracking id is: '%s+%s'" % (logbook.uuid, flow_detail.uuid)) print("!! Please submit this on later runs for tracking purposes") else: flow_detail = find_flow_detail(backend, book_id, flow_id) # Annnnd load and run. engine_conf = { 'engine': 'parallel', } engine = engines.load(flow, flow_detail=flow_detail, backend=backend, engine_conf=engine_conf) engine.run()

Your tracking id is: '%s+%s'" % (logbook.uuid, flow_detail.uuid)) print("!! commit_message:
Mess around with eventlet

Instead of keeping an active pool of greenthreads
'spinning' (greenthreads don't really spin) even
when the queue is empty spin up new greenthreads
as needed and when the queue is empty, let the
existing greenthreads exit cleanly.

Change-Id: Ifa75a35ffe678dcd93bb723e6ae572b75fc550d1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/52/51352/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from eventlet.green import time def __init__(self, executor, back_log, work_item, worker_id): self.back_log = back_log self.work_item = work_item # First run my specified work, then attempt to clear out the # back log, if there is nothing in the back log, then we just # finish up. self.work_item.run() # Don't hold onto the object, GC can then commence. self.work_item = None # Allow green-thread switch. time.sleep(0) while True: try: work = self.back_log.get(block=False) except queue.Empty: # Allow green-thread switch. time.sleep(0) self._back_log = queue.LightQueue() self._worker_count = 0 self._spin_up(w) def _spin_up(self, work_item): cur_am = self._pool.running() + self._pool.waiting() if cur_am < self._max_workers: self._worker_count += 1 worker = _Worker(self, self._back_log, work_item, self._worker_count) else: # NOTE(harlowja): put the piece of work in the back log for # an active thread to consume. Since all threads check the back # log before they finish there should never be a piece of work # in the back log that is unfinished. self._back_log.put(work_item)
deleted_lines: # NOTE(harlowja): this object signals to threads that they should stop # working and rest in peace. _TOMBSTONE = object() def __init__(self, executor, work_queue, worker_id): self.work_queue = work_queue while True: work = self.work_queue.get(block=True) if work is _TOMBSTONE: # NOTE(harlowja): give notice to other workers (this is # basically a chain of tombstone calls that will cause all # the workers on the queue to eventually shut-down). self.work_queue.put(_TOMBSTONE) self._work_queue = queue.LightQueue() self._work_queue.put(w) self._spin_up() def _spin_up(self): cur_am = (self._pool.running() + self._pool.waiting()) if cur_am < self._max_workers and cur_am < self._work_queue.qsize(): # Spin up a new worker to do the work as we are behind. worker = _Worker(self, self._work_queue, cur_am + 1) self._work_queue.put(_TOMBSTONE)

commit_message:
Add the start of a item registry

A item registry is useful to be able to easily
and centrally register tasks/flows (or other
things that have a uuid property) for others
to use (or find based on a known set of
attributes).

Change-Id: I99b96dcfef0edb826d19f71848f06e50f8457711

added_lines: # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # Copyright (C) 2012 Yahoo! Inc. All Rights Reserved. # Copyright (C) 2013 Rackspace Hosting All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import collections from taskflow import exceptions as exc class UnauthorizedExtraction(exc.TaskFlowException): pass class NoopPolicyCheck(object): def __call__(self, context, task): return True class TaskRegistry(object): """A registry of tasks This registry can act as a standard place to store various kind of tasks for later finding based on various attributes of the tasks stored. It also allows for a policy to be provided while registering which will limit the ability to be extracted based on an arbitary policy. Furthermore attributes can be associated with the tasks that are registered which can then be used to later locate tasks with the specified attributes. """ def __init__(self): self._registry = {} self._attribute_to_tasks = collections.defaultdict(list) def register(self, task, attributes=None, extraction_policy=None): if not extraction_policy: extraction_policy = NoopPolicyCheck() assert isinstance(task, collections.Callable) assert isinstance(extraction_policy, collections.Callable) self._registry[task.uuid] = (task, extraction_policy) if attributes: for k in attributes: self._attribute_to_tasks[k].append(task.uuid) def match(self, attribute, *attributes): matches = set(self._attribute_to_tasks[attribute]) for k in attributes: matches2 = set(self._attribute_to_tasks[k]) matches = matches.intersection(matches2) if not matches: break return matches def fetch(self, context, task_uuid): try: task, extraction_policy = self._registry[task_uuid] if extraction_policy(context, task): return task else: raise UnauthorizedExtraction("Unauthorized fetch of %s" " requested" % (task_uuid)) except KeyError: raise exc.NotFound("Unable to find task with id: %s" % task_uuid)

commit_message:
Remove the property validate for stack-adopt

Adopt a stack means to create the stack with the existing resources, so no
need to validate the property for the existing resources.

Change-Id: I4b1807488003014125edc8e901c84f8634155f70
Closes-Bug: #1297157

subject: VMWare: Enable live migration with one nova compute (WIP)
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-31 08:56:12.000000000', 'files': ['nova/conductor/tasks/live_migrate.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/b60663e197118b02802839880b34815d4eef27cd', 'message': 'VMWare: Enable live migration with one nova compute (WIP)

Currently with VMWare VCDriver, one nova compute can manage multiple
cluster/RP, this caused cluster admin cannot do live migration between
clusters/PRs if those clusters/PRs managed by one nova compute.

The fix was trying to do the following to enable live migration with
one nova compute:
1) When live migration check if host are same, check both host and
node for the VM instance.
2) When nova scheduler select destination for live migration, the live
migration task should put (host, node) to attempted hosts.
3) Nova scheduler needs to be enhanced to support ignored_nodes.

Change-Id: I06a20dba22932d81d43b67f99817748f450d04bb
Partial-Bug: #1192192
'}]
commit_message:
VMWare: Enable live migration with one nova compute (WIP)

Currently with VMWare VCDriver, one nova compute can manage multiple
cluster/RP, this caused cluster admin cannot do live migration between
clusters/PRs if those clusters/PRs managed by one nova compute.

The fix was trying to do the following to enable live migration with
one nova compute:
1) When live migration check if host are same, check both host and
node for the VM instance.
2) When nova scheduler select destination for live migration, the live
migration task should put (host, node) to attempted hosts.
3) Nova scheduler needs to be enhanced to support ignored_nodes.

Change-Id: I06a20dba22932d81d43b67f99817748f450d04bb
Partial-Bug: #1192192
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/85/84085/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Separate muranodashboard.settings from openstack_dashboard.settings
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-01-21 14:28:55.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/murano-dashboard/commit/d8504c85812a0cf7f9f2e072cb663fb9b76ae239', 'message': "Separate muranodashboard.settings from openstack_dashboard.settings

The idea is to specify muranodashboard.settings as
DJANGO_SETTIGNS_MODULE in apache config/ WSGI wrapper, then import
openstack_dashboard.settings from muranodashboard.settings. Thus we
touch neither openstack_dashboard.settings (which is vanilla
openstack_dashboard settings), nor local.local_settings (which is
openstack_dashboard customization module for admins).

Furthermore, all muranodashboard settings which are really could be
modified (directories, different modes specified in settings) are
moved out to a separate file similar to local.local_settings. Sadly,
there have to be 2 such files, because of DATABASES &
openstack_dashboard.policy issue. First specifies actual DATABASES
(before statement 'from openstack_dashboard import policy' is
executed), second specifies all the rest parameters.

This commit is not a working solution for production environments,
because it should be accompanied with following changes in setup
script. Also, fixing LOGOUT_URL was dropped out because it is
distro-specific (LOGOUT_URL = '{horizon,dashboard}/auth/logout' for
{Ubuntu,CentOS}).

Change-Id: I455efeb5ee7825ac69eba2d1a3f4aefcef3dda81

commit_message:
Separate muranodashboard.settings from openstack_dashboard.settings

The idea is to specify muranodashboard.settings as
DJANGO_SETTIGNS_MODULE in apache config/ WSGI wrapper, then import
openstack_dashboard.settings from muranodashboard.settings. Thus we
touch neither openstack_dashboard.settings (which is vanilla
openstack_dashboard settings), nor local.local_settings (which is
openstack_dashboard customization module for admins).

Furthermore, all muranodashboard settings which are really could be
modified (directories, different modes specified in settings) are
moved out to a separate file similar to local.local_settings. Sadly,
there have to be 2 such files, because of DATABASES &
openstack_dashboard.policy issue. First specifies actual DATABASES
(before statement 'from openstack_dashboard import policy' is
executed), second specifies all the rest parameters.

All required changes in apache config are made by setup.sh script.

Closes-Bug: #1267737
Change-Id: I455efeb5ee7825ac69eba2d1a3f4aefcef3dda81
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano-dashboard refs/changes/25/68125/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import os import tempfile METADATA_CACHE_DIR = os.path.join(tempfile.gettempdir(), 'muranodashboard-cache') if not os.path.exists(METADATA_CACHE_DIR): os.makedirs(METADATA_CACHE_DIR) DATABASES = { 'default': { 'ENGINE': 'django.db.backends.sqlite3', 'NAME': os.path.join(METADATA_CACHE_DIR, 'openstack-dashboard.sqlite') } }

commit_message:
Introduce Hitachi Block Storage Driver

Introduce Hitachi Block Storage Driver for Hitachi VSP, HUS-VM and HUS arrays
with Fibre Channel and iSCSI.

This will support all features required in Icehouse:
* Volume Create/Delete
* Volume Attach/Detach
* Snapshot Create/Delete
* Create Volume from Snapshot
* Copy Image to Volume
* Copy Volume to Image
* Clone Volume
* Extend Volume

Implements: blueprint hitachi-block-storage-driver

Change-Id: I110e4d821e30ee8b140e3c83654b039ce3ce0fc9
Signed-off-by: Seiji Aguchi <seiji.aguchi.tr@hitachi.com>

commit_message:
Add test for keystone-manage db_version

There was no test that ran the `keystone-manage db_version`
subcommand.

Change-Id: Icc9f58e32fb6c2a629f7be47fcad6fd70bebdf51
Closes-Bug: #1284341

added_lines: # Copyright 2014 IBM Corp. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import subprocess from tempest import cli from tempest import config from tempest.openstack.common import log as logging LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) CONF = config.CONF class TestKeystoneManage(cli.ClientTestBase): """Read-only keystone-manage commands. These tests exercise READ-ONLY keystone-manage command invocations. """ def test_db_version(self): """Simple call to ``db_version`` subcommand.""" output = subprocess.check_output(['keystone-manage', 'db_version']) LOG.info('db_version: %s', output) output = output.split('\n') # The first line is the version, which is a number. self.assertTrue(int(output[0]) > 0)

"}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2014-01-29 06:11:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/d7186bf309fd6f86f90d6d4a04a69798da0ff72f', 'message': "PCI whitelist support pci_infomation

'pci-information' combine the whitelist and extra infomation.

The pci-information can be define multiple times:
pci_information = [{pci-regex}, {pci-extra-attrs}]
pci-regex is a dict of { string-key: string-value } pairs ,
it can only match device properties, like vendor_id, address,
product_id,etc.
pci-extra-attrs is a dict of {string-key:string-value} pairs.
The values can be arbitrary.all this extra attrs will be store
in the pci device table's extra info field.

whitelist is deprecated.

bp:pci-extra-info
Sined-off-by: Yongli He <yongli.he@intel.com>
Change-Id: Ida2911ebe14cfb03362dbb8e06aaf35f590f2c28

commit_message:
PCI whitelist support pci_infomation

'pci-information' combine the whitelist and extra infomation.

Pci-information can be define multiple times like
pci_information = [{pci-regex}, {pci-extra-attrs}], where
pci-regex is a dict of { string-key: string-value } pairs,
it can only match device properties, like vendor_id, address,
product_id, etc.
Pci-extra-attrs is a dict of {string-key:string-value} pairs.
The values can be arbitrary. All the extra attrs will be store
in the pci device table's extra info field.

whitelist is deprecated.

bp:pci-extra-info
Sined-off-by: Yongli He <yongli.he@intel.com>
Change-Id: Ida2911ebe14cfb03362dbb8e06aaf35f590f2c28

commit_message:
WIP: Create metafiles for API v3 samples

Create metafiles for the API v3 samples which can be used to
help automate the generation of specification documentation for
the v3 API

Adds the infrastructure for creating the meta files plus adds
the changes for hosts extension

Partially implements blueprint v3-api-specification

Change-Id: Ie443931ea6bb49fbf2848f2223d0e47436005c8f

commit_message:
VMware: Use server-side views to retrieve objects

Repeatedly queried inventory objects can be retrieved efficiently
using server-side views. These views are stored in the server and
are constantly refreshed. This patch adds a helper method to the
VMware driver utility.

Operations like retrieving list of VM's, list of host's managed by
a cluster can be refactored to use this helper utility, and make a
single api call to retrieve objects.

WIP: Adding tests
implements blueprint vmware-use-views

Change-Id: I65ba24a9d2254727cfd5c836a7becb0325e40b98
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/58/69258/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def build_object_spec(client_factory, root_folder, traversal_specs, skip=False): object_spec.skip = skipdef _get_container_view(vim, parent_obj, child_type, recursive=False): """Returns a new or cached container view.""" # A container view is a mechanism that supports selection of objects on the # server and subsequently, access to those objects. They simplify the task # of retrieving data from the server. view_mgr = vim.get_service_content().viewManager vim_cache_key = (parent_obj, child_type, recursive) cached_container_view = vim.get_cache_entry(vim_cache_key) if cached_container_view: # This container view exists until you destroy it or until the end of # the session. container_view = cached_container_view else: container_view = vim.CreateContainerView( view_mgr, container=parent_obj, type=[child_type], recursive=recursive) vim.init_cache_entry(vim_cache_key, container_view) return container_view def get_contained_objects(vim, parent_obj, child_type, properties=None, recursive=False): """Gets the child objects of a given parent object and child type""" client_factory = vim.client.factory collector = vim.get_service_content().propertyCollector # Get a container view object container_view = _get_container_view(vim, parent_obj, child_type, recursive) # Create a filter spec for the requested properties property_spec = build_property_spec(client_factory, type=child_type, properties_to_collect=properties, all_properties=False) # Traversal spec determines the object traversal path to search for the # specified property. The following is the default for a container view. traversal_spec = build_traversal_spec(client_factory, "view", "ContainerView", "view", False, None) # Create an object spec with the traversal spec object_spec = build_object_spec(client_factory, container_view, [traversal_spec], True) # Create a property filter spec with the property spec & object spec property_filter_spec = client_factory.create('ns0:PropertyFilterSpec') property_filter_spec.propSet = [property_spec] property_filter_spec.objectSet = [object_spec] options = client_factory.create('ns0:RetrieveOptions') options.maxObjects = CONF.vmware.maximum_objects return vim.RetrievePropertiesEx(collector, specSet=[property_filter_spec], options=options)
deleted_lines: def build_object_spec(client_factory, root_folder, traversal_specs): object_spec.skip = False

commit_message:
VMware: simple cache for storing session data

Implements a simple cache for storing objects during the length
of a session.
WIP : Adding tests

implements blueprint vmware-use-views
Change-Id: I1ae9a05fc8f14bfe71d6fc99d0328d75efe99252

added_lines: self._vim_cache = {} def get_cache_entry(self, key): """Gets object from the session cache""" return self._vim_cache.get(key) def init_cache_entry(self, key, value): """Stores object into the session cache""" self._vim_cache[key] = value def delete_cache_entry(self, key, value): """Stores object into the session cache""" del self._vim_cache[key] def clear_cache(self): """Clears the cache entries""" self._vim_cache.clear()

commit_message:
Port assisted_volume_snapshots extensions to V3 API

Ports the assisted_volume_snapshots extension from V2 to V3 API
along with the unittests and api samples. Adds the expected_error
decorators and validation schema.

Partially implements blueprint nova-v3-api

Change-Id: I42850e8e2fbcad9d54645f986f1993d023814f20

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from nova.compute import api as compute_api from nova.tests.api.openstack import fakes from nova.tests.integrated.v3 import api_sample_base class AssistedVolumeSnapshotsJsonTest(api_sample_base.ApiSampleTestBaseV3): """Assisted volume snapshots.""" extension_name = "os-assisted-volume-snapshots" def _create_assisted_snapshot(self, subs): self.stubs.Set(compute_api.API, 'volume_snapshot_create', fakes.stub_compute_volume_snapshot_create) response = self._do_post("os-assisted-volume-snapshots", "snapshot-create-assisted-req", subs) return response def test_snapshots_create_assisted(self): subs = { 'snapshot_name': 'snap-001', 'description': 'Daily backup', 'volume_id': '521752a6-acf6-4b2d-bc7a-119f9148cd8c', 'snapshot_id': '421752a6-acf6-4b2d-bc7a-119f9148cd8c', 'type': 'qcow', 'new_file': 'new_file_name' } subs.update(self._get_regexes()) response = self._create_assisted_snapshot(subs) self._verify_response("snapshot-create-assisted-resp", subs, response, 200) def test_snapshots_delete_assisted(self): self.stubs.Set(compute_api.API, 'volume_snapshot_delete', fakes.stub_compute_volume_snapshot_delete) snapshot_id = '100' response = self._do_delete( 'os-assisted-volume-snapshots/%s?delete_info=' '{"volume_id":"521752a6-acf6-4b2d-bc7a-119f9148cd8c"}' % snapshot_id) self.assertEqual(response.status, 204) self.assertEqual(response.read(), '')

commit_message:
Add migration to fix nullable params

In some tables nullable param for column doesn't correspond to one
declared in model. This migration syncronizes nullable params in
db and in models for following tables and columns:

- pci_devices (deleted, dev_type, product_id, vendor_id)
- quota_usages (resource)

Implements blueprint db-sync-models-with-migrations

Change-Id: Iaefafa9344d1ef72ac43b8495d0ebdebcdaa7e28
